Improvements in Gun Mountings for Aeroplanes.
column13: 131,101. Allen, R. May 24, 1918. Mountings for use on aircraft.-Relates to mountings, for use on aeroplanes, of the kind comprising a forwardly extending girder, adapted to be attached to the top plane, and a downwardly curved quadrant having a 'sliding block carrying the gun mounted thereon under the influence of springs which exert an upward and forward pull, as described in Specification 124,872. According to the invention, the main parts of the mounting are constructed of tubing and stampings, or entirely of stampings. In the construetion shown in Figs 1 and 4, the girder a and quadrant b are formed of a single length of rectangular tubing with the addition at the front of a stamping c to form the tapered part of the girder. The slide block f is formed of two stampings f<1>, Fig. 4, connected by cross-bolts. In a modification, Figs. 5 and 8, the quadrant is formed of two stampings b<1>, U-shaped in crosssection, united by cross-plates m. The girder a is a stamping, but the same quadrant could be attached to a tubular girder.

column12: Dispositif permettant d'insérer les segments de pistons dans leurs rainures ou de les en retirer
INK TRANSFER ROLLER WITH A REMOVABLE HOLLOW-CORE ELASTOMER ROLLER BODY ON A REUSABLE HANGER SHAFT
column13: An ink transfer roller with a hollow-core elastomer roller body is carried on a reusable hanger shaft. Bearings reduce friction while the steel shaft dissipates heat more readily than the aluminum shaft used in conventional transfer rollers. The hollow-core elastomer roller body reduces heat transfer from the shaft to the roller body. A lock collar on one end and a snap ring on the other end of the roller body hold the roller body in place on the shaft. A set screw can be tightened to secure the lock collar to the shaft to hold the roller in place. These features allow the roller body to be easily removed and replaced on the shaft, which reduces maintenance costs. The hangers on the ends of the shaft allow a fully assembled ink transfer roller to be easily removed and replaced in the printing machine, which further reduces maintenance costs.

column12: AN ADJUSTABLE ALARM DEVICE FOR SLIDING DOORS AND WINDOWS
column13: An adjustable alarm device for windows and doors is installed between the door or window frame and the door or window sash. The longitudinal axis of the alarm device is preferably horizontal. When engaged, movement of the door or window in an open direction will activate the alarm. The body of the alarm device is elongate, tubular and telescoping. The body comprises an outer tube that receives an inner tube. The body of the alarm device may be locked in an extended position by way of a cam mounted on the inner tube and positioned within the body so that when the inner and outer tubes of the body are twisted about their longitudinal axis, the cam body will engage the inner surface of the outer tube in a releasable frictional locking engagement. The alarm device is coupled to one end of the inner tube.

column12: Improvements in or connected with Gauges or Measuring Appliances.
Improvements in or connected with Traction Engines, Road Locomotives and the like.
column13: 12,602. Allen, R. June 17. Traction engines and road locomotives; motor road vehicles.-Relates to draw-gear or couplings for traction engines, road locomotives, and the like, and consists in mounting the draw-gear so that it is free to adjust itself vertically, and in providing springs to reduce shocks. Figs. 1 and 2 show one form in which side bars a are pivotally mounted at their forward ends on the main axle bearing hubs, and provided at their rear ends with side flanges b which form housings for springs c and guides for the coupling-bar d. Brackets k limit the vertical movement of the draw-gear. A weaker spring may be enclosed within each spring c to act for light loads and bold the cross-bar in its normal position. In the modification shown in Fig. 4, the side bars a are bifurcated to clear the axle, and are connected at their forward ends by springs f to the dead pins g. In further modifications, laminated springs connect the side bars a and coupling-bar d instead of the spiral springs shown in Figs. 1 and 2.

column12: Improvements in or connected with Steam Generators and the like.
column13: 17,201. Allen, R. Aug. 27. Drawings to Specification. Casings. -Relates to means for utilizing the waste heat of steam boilers, either the radiant heat or the heat of the waste gases, or both, for heating the air supply to the furnace. A Cornish or locomotive boiler may be provided with a casing, through which air passes to the furnace.

column12: METALLIC PACKING FOR STUFFING-BOXES, &C.
Improvements in and connected with Street Sweeping Appliances.
column13: 24,788. Allen, R. Nov. 11. Sweeping-machines.-A road-sweeping machine shown in plan in Fig. 2 is constructed with two disc brushes f mounted on inclined spindles g and driven in opposite directions by bevel gearing m and chain gearing i from one of the supporting- wheels c. The brushes are raised or lowered by oscillating the frame a on the axle d. The brushes sweep dust or mud into a central ridge, or deliver it into a removable tray. In another machine, adapted to work close to the kerb, a single disc brush f, Fig. 3, is mounted on a spindle h working in a frame h<1>, which can be adjusted to any required angle by means of nuts h<3>. The frame a is supported at the front by a castor wheel c<1>, the stem c<3> cf which can be adjusted by a rack and pinion and secured at any required height by an eye-bolt c<6> and nut c<7>. The handles a<1> are adjusted by means of segmental slots a'. The brush spindle h is driven by bevel gearing and by one of two sets of chains and chain-wheels giving two different speeds. The two driving chain-wheels j<1>, k<1>, Fig. 5, are mounted loosely on a spindle d<1> driven by spur gearing j<2>, j<3> from the axle d of the main supporting-wheels c. Two discs k<2>, k<3> with projecting studs are feathered to the spindle d<1>, so that one or the other of them can be clutched to its respective chain-wheel j<1> or k<1> by means of a roller o<3> on a lever o fitted with a locking-pin for holding it in the required position. Bar magnets in the spur-wheel j<3> cause the return of the discs k', k'. The main wheels c are connected to the axle by ratchet clutches d' held in engagement by springs d<3> or bar magnets d<4>. The spindle d' is mounted in a yoke frame o<2>, which can be adjusted along concentric slots p, q for tightening the chains. These machines may be worked by horse or manual power. The Provisional Specification states that the machine may have a rotary brush mounted on a horizontal spindle ; that the collecting-tray has a hinged flap at its lower edge with a number of projections or spikes turned up at their ends to prevent the tray from catching stones ; that this flap may be in several narrow pieces so as to adapt itself to an uneven surface ; that auxiliary brushes or scrapers are mounted behind the main brushes to take the sweepings into a receptacle placed above ; and that the brush spindle may be driven direct from the road wheel by an annular toothed wheel and a pinion.

column12: Gudgeon-pin bush for pistons
Container with indicating closure
column13: A container for pharmaceuticals and the like has a cap-like closure incorporating an indicator disk which is automatically indexed into successive indicating positions each time the container is used by removal and replacement of the closure. The container also has a manually operable rotary reminder wheel on its base. The disk may be used to indicate days of the week and the wheel to indicate hours of the day.

PISTON
Improvements in Pump and similar Pistons or Plungers.
column13: 24,347. Allen, R. Oct. 24. Piston packing.- Packing for pump and similar pistons or plungers is made of vulcanite or similar material, preferably backed with metal. The packing may be used in conjunction with the non-expanding follower or clamping rings described in Specification 26,668/10. The packing, which is contained in grooves in the piston body, consists of vulcanite segments c, Fig. 1, having metal backing-pieces b, and expanded by wedges d having vulcanite tips d'. The wedges are formed with shanks e, entering holes in the piston body and containing springs f. The wedges are formed with extensions d<2> to cover the joints. In a modification, the wedges are formed with flanges which cover the joints. The wedges may be formed without the shanks e, the springs f then resting on the bottom of the packing-ring groove. In this case, rotation of the packing is prevented by a peg in the piston body engaging one of the wedges.

column12: PISTON.
Improvements in Steam Superheaters for Locomotive, Marine and other Boilers.
column13: 23,838. Allen, R. Oct. 18. Cleaning, fluid-pressure processes for; metal pipes and tubes. - The smoke-tubes traversing a superheating- chamber are cleaned by passing steam into them from a steam space provided in the chamber. In a superheater consisting of adjacent chambers c<1> traversed by smoke tubes a, formed with internal and external helical ribs, as described in Specification 15,574/12 steam is admitted to a space h between the chambers. from which it passes into the tubes through perforations k. Partitions in the space ensure the equal distribution of steam to the tubes.

column12: An Improved Packing for Piston Rods and the like.
column13: 26,674. Allen, R. Nov. 16. Packing, metallic; boxes. - In packing consisting of both solid and divided rings, the segments of the divided rings are formed with parallel ends, and are pressed both radially and axially. Fig. 3 shows plungers h with wedge surfaces engaging similar surfaces on the segments of the divided rings. The plungers h are formed with tongues i covering the joints between the segments. The divided rings bare placed between undivided rings a, which fit the rod, and the whole is enclosed in sleeves k. Other undivided rings a<1> are loose on the rod, and fit the interior of the stuffing-box. In a modification, the divided rings are pressed radially by spring plungers, and usually by helical or other springs. The divided rings b, Fig. 5, are arranged in pairs with bevelled surfaces forming grooves to receive spring rings j. Each pair of divided rings b is ar-' ranged between solid rings a, a', and is enclosed in a sleeve k. Two groups of rings are separated by a solid ring l. The rings a, a<1> may be grooved internally, and one of the sleeves k may be dispensed with. One group of rings may be replaced by soft packing. The divided rings b, Fig. 7, are pushed inwards by inclined springs p contained in cups p'. The packing is supplemented by soft packing m contained in a conically bored sleeve n.

column12: METHOD OF MANUFACTURING METAL TUBES.
Marine propulsion device
column13: A device for adapting a brush cutter or whipper snipper to perform as a marine propulsion unit is disclosed. The brush cutter or whipper snipper must have an engine driving a first shaft (2) rotatably mounted within an outer shaft. The device includes a two or three bladed propeller with low pitched blades (5) connected to a second shaft (4), and a propeller housing that supports the second shaft. A set of brass drive inserts (6-8) of particular shapes are used to connect the first and second shafts to allow the propeller to be driven by the engine. The propeller can be used for propulsion of a small watercraft.

column12: Ergonomic finger guide for biometric finger scanner
column13: A finger guide device for a biometric fingerprint scanner, the device including a raised portion, a channel formed into the raised portion and extending from about a front side of the raised portion to about a rear side thereof, an aperture formed through the device at the channel, finger selection contours configured to visually indicate to a user to place an index finger in the channel, and finger direction contours configured to direct a finger placed in the channel toward the aperture.

column12: FURNACE-GRATE.
Improvements in Heating Apparatus.
column13: 16,866. Allen, R. July 23. Heating liquids; heating gases.-A tubular feedwater-heater, Fig. 2, consists of a series of straight water-pipes d connecting heaters c, around which pipes live or exhaust steam circulates while the water is caused to flow repeatedly across the steam space by the heaters. The pipes d are fitted with rods e extending across the heater so as to limit the water to a narrow annular passage. Some of the rods may be provided with a screw-thread and nuts at the end to act as stays for the heater. Fig. 4 shows another form of feedwater-heater. The water passes under chambers or tubes o<4>, which are in communication with a steam chamber o<6>, and may be perforated, thus heating the water by actual contact with steam. Baffles may be provided. Holes permit the escape of gases from the feed-water. A sludge channel u is put in communication with any desired part of the heater by valves t, and the sludge is blown off through a valve u<1>. This form of heater may be built up from parts bolted together ; it may have only one pendent steam chamber, which, according to the Provisional Specification, may be fitted with a helical rib to direct the passage of water. The feed-water may be passed through the two heaters shown in Figs. 2 and 4 successively. One section of the heater may be utilized as a surface condenser, while other sections may be fed with live steam so as to raise the temperature of the feed-water to as high a degree as possible. In the Provisional Specification it is stated that the apparatus might be used for heating any liquid or gas.

column13: 3935. Allen, R. Feb. 17. Piston packing. -In piston packing-rings expanded by radial wedges, the flanges for covering the joints are formed on the wedges and are received in slots in the packing-rings, or vice versa. Fig. 1 shows a wedge with side flanges c, and Fig. 3<a> shows a wedge formed by plates b<1>, b<2> on a shank b<4>, which extends upwards between the plates, the ends of the ring being formed as shown in Fig. 3<b>. The wedge shown in Fig. 5 has a flange c, and an inclined slot f in which a bevelled plunger is pressed axially by a spring. Two bevelled packing-rings may be arranged in the same piston groove, the wedge of one ring being formed with a flange, and the wedge of the other ring without a flange. As shown in Fig. 7, a wedge formed with a slot at one side or both for the reception of ribs on the packing-ring, is acted on by a leaf or other spring i. Three bevelled packing-rings may be arranged in the same piston groove, and be expanded by separate wedges correspondingly shaped. In the form shown in Fig. 13, a wedge is expanded by a spring i, and displacement of the wedge is prevented by a projection k<1> formed on, or secured to, a band or ring k. The packing-ring may also be expanded by leaf springs placed between the wedges. In a modification, the wedges are expanded by springs broader than the wedges and contained in slots in the piston body, which is built up from plates. Reference has been directed by the Comptroller to Specification 3886/08.

Improvements in Explosive Shells or Projectiles.
column13: 113,975. Allen, R. Jan. 3, 1916. Projectiles.-Consists in making shells pointed and heavy at the base so that when discharged at a high angle they fall base downwards and penetrate surface armours and earth coverings. In the form shown in Fig. 2, the heavy pointed base a is screwed to the body d against a washer c. In a modification, Fig. 3, the shell is cast in one piece over a central rod f of iron or steel. The front end of the rod is recessed to hold the 'gaine,' and is screw-threaded to receive the nose piece b. The rod f may be screwed to the base instead of being cast in. The explosive chamber x may widen out forwards.

column12: Animal urging assembly
column13: An animal urging assembly, e.g. head restraint for a cattle crush, comprises an engagement member or restraining arm engageable with an animal, e.g. a neck yoke or chin scoop. The assembly is configured to move the arm between a vertically extending out-of-use position and a transversely extending in-use position so that the arm pivots from its vertical orientation to its horizontal orientation as it moves along a vertical path from its out-of-use position toward its in-use position. Preferably, the arm 34 has a pivot 60 slidably engaging a vertical channel 37, and two spaced guide wheels 40, 42 engaging an L-shaped guideway 38, that turn the arm as it slides along the vertical slot 37 and the nonlinear track 38, so that the concurrent translation and rotation is effected by a single actuator, e.g. a vertically acting hydraulic cylinder (26, Fig. 3). A second such assembly may be inverted relative to the first so that, when mounted on a livestock chute head-gate, their opposed restraining arms engage the upper and lower surfaces of an animal’s head or neck.

column12: Improvements in Pistons, Piston Valves or the like.
column13: 3886. Allen, R. Feb. 20. Pistons.-In piston, piston-valve, and like packing, wherein the packing-rings are expanded by radial wedges inserted in the joints of the rings and provided with extensions for covering the joints, the adjacent rings are arranged so that the joints and the expanding-wedges are side by side. With narrow rings, the shanks of the wedges d, d', Fig. 20, are cut away on their inner faces, and the expanding springs are flattened on one or both sides. Thin plates may be used to separate the springs, or the wedges may be forced out by plates or laminated springs, pins d<2>, Fig. 26, entering the piston body and fixed in the wedges, forming guides for the wedges. With three packing-rings a, a<1>, a<2>, Fig. 6, and wedges d for each ring, the shank of the central wedge is not cut away ; or the central wedge is formed with two shanks d<4>, Fig. 24, round which springs are placed, the springs for the outer wedges acting at the centre of these wedges. With three rings, having two wedges at each joint, the shanks are not cut away, and the centre ring bears 'on the outer rings and is prevented from rotation by a pin, which is fixed in the piston or other body and engages the centre ring. As shown in Fig. 24, the wedges have side flanges j to cover the joint, the wedge surfaces not extending to the outside of the packing-rings. With wide rings, the wedge shanks. are not cut away, and the springs may be circular. The wedges d, Figs. 14 and 15, are undercut so as to cover in part the wedges d, these wedges having a projecting portion d<3> to cover the joint. For larger pistons, the packing-rings are supported by spring-pressed plugs h, Fig. 20, having prolongations h<1> to allow the plugs to be depressed. To prevent interlocking of the wedges, a soft metal liner may be placed between them ; or the adjacent lateral faces of pairs of opposed wedges are cut at different angles to leave a clearance between them. A strip of steel bent at intervals may be used to form the expanding-spring.

column13: 5108. Allen, R. March 2. Plate apparatus.-In a steam traction engine; locomotive or the like, an air-cooled condenser shown in transverse section in Fig. 4 is employed. It consists of thin plates j clamped together in pairs between rectangular frames k of channel-section, placed side by side and secured by bolts passing through bolt holes in the sides and ends of the frames. The spaces between the two plates of each pair extend from one end of the condenser to the other, and open into the exhaust-steam and condensedwater headers at the ends. The air passages k<1> alternate with the steam passages and open at the ends into headers bolted to the underside of the condenser through perforations in the lower sides of the rectangular frames.

column12: GUDGEON PIN BUSH FOR PISTONS
An Improved Appliance for Inserting Piston Rings or the like in their Grooves or Removing them therefrom.
column13: 124,285. Allen, R. March 21, 1918. Packing, tools for inserting or removing.-In apparatus for inserting piston-rings &c. in their grooves, the piston-ring is placed in a ring a of angular section, and is retained by stops k. Two brackets b, c riding on the periphery of the ring a carry pins d, e which project through slots in the ring a and enter the joint of the piston-ring. The brackets b, c are pressed apart by an interposed spring, or by toggle-levers, or, as shown, by a nut m<1> on a screw m which is pivoted to the bracket band passes through apertures in a fork on the bracket c. The piston-ring is pressed towards the pins d, e by a pin i, which is limited in its movement by a pin i<1>, and is pressed inwards by hand or by a blade spring. The piston-ring may be retained in its forward position by blades or springs secured to the ring a and pressed under the ends of the piston-ring. Alternatively, one of the brackets b, c may be rigidly secured to the ring a.

column12: Dichtung für Kolben und Kolbenschieber.
PLATFORM FOR THE PURCHASE AND SALE OF DIGITAL CURRENCY
column13: A platform for buyers and sellers of digital currency is disclosed. The platform comprises different modules which can be used alone or in combination. When used together, they provide for a fully automated experience for a user, from account sign-up through to funds settlement. Using the platform, a buyer or seller can participate in virtually instantaneous transactions of digital currency. The platform can be expanded to buy and sell other commodities in addition to digital currency. The platform can permit users to fund or settle accounts using commodities such as gold rather than a globally traded currency.

Improvements in or connected with Piston and like Packing.
column13: 19,979. Allen, R. Sept. 19. Pistons; piston packing.-In order to adapt segmental packing-rings expanded by lateral springs or plungers, as described in Specification 11,480/13, to pistons without removable junk rings or plates, the springs are contained in a segmental housing- ring made of a light metal, such as aluminium or aluminium alloy. Fig. 1 shows a segmental packing-ring c expanded by plungers f acted on by springs e contained in a segmental housing-ring d. The latter ring is formed with a tongue g, which enters a recess in the wall of the groove. Rotation of the ring d may be prevented by a pin secured in the piston and entering a notch in the ring. Holes j may be formed in the piston to permit the escape of oil from the groove. The wedges i, Fig. 6, between the ends of the segments of the packing- ring are also acted on by spring plungers. The bevelled surfaces of the wedges may be cut away, as shown by dotted lines. In the modification shown in Fig. 7, the housing-ring is formed with flanges which enter recesses g<1>, g<2> in the packing- ring groove. The sockets for the springs e may be formed separately and secured in the ring d. Fig. 11 shows the employment of axial springs and plungers e, f contained in recesses in a tread ring d and acting on segmental expanding rings l, which are held in position by projections f<1> on the plungers. Alternatively, separate springs e may be employed for the two packing-rings c, the recesses on one side of the ring d being out of line with those in the other side of the ring. The parts of the ring d are secured together by studs k, Fig. 10, screwed between the ends of the segments and having undercut heads which engage recesses in the ends of the segments.

column12: Improvements in Metallic Packings for Stuffing Boxes and the like.
column13: 17,437. Allen, R. July 30. Stuffing-boxes.-The segments of packing-rings a, Fig. 11, are drawn together by plungers e, Fig, 2, entering notches a<1> in the ends of the segments. Each plunger is formed with a recess or with a shank for a spring g, and has projections e3, Fig. 4, covering the joint in the packing ring. The rings a lie in recesses between rings c, Fig. 11, which form spigot-and-socket joints with one another, and are held together by bolts d. The rings a are pressed laterally by plungers h. The rings c may be arranged to float, as shown, in order to allow lateral motion of the shaft, and may be pressed axially by spring plungers or a spring k in the gland. The rings c may be dispensed with, the packing-rings a being placed in recesses in the box j. In a modification, the plungers h are dispensed with, each ring a being pressed axially by the action of a bevelled ring acting on a bevelled surface on the ring a. A single bevelled ring may be placed between two rings a. In the further modification shown in Fig. 22, the casing containing the rings a is formed by four rings c, the outer rings c having a concave and a convex surface engaging the neck bush j<4> and a soft metal ring j<3> carried by the gland j<2>, respectively. The rings c may be surrounded by a sleeve c<7>, and may be expanded axially by a spring n.

column12: CORN HARVESTER
Improvements in Pistons, Piston Valves and the like.
column13: 22,713. Allen, R. Oct. 14. Piston packing.-The expanding effect of the steam or other pressure medium at the back of a split packing-ring of a piston or piston valve is balanced by allowing the steam to press the ring against the side of the groove, the depth of the ring being from five to eight times the width of its rubbing surface. The ring is undercut in order to preserve the relation between the depth and width as wear takes place. The split ring a, Fig. 2, is pressed against one side of the groove by springs c enclosed in caps d. The springs may be arranged in recesses in the ring a, as shown, or in recesses in the piston body. An expanding-wedge c at the joint in the ring is pressed outwards by inclined springs f. In a modification, the sides of the groove are inclined, and the springs c press the ring a outwards as well as axially. The helical springs c may be replaced by leaf springs. Fig. 10 shows a split ring a expanded by a solid bevelled ring k. In the arrangement shown in Fig. 12, the ring a is gripped between an outer ring and the side of the groove. The ring a is cut away at a<1> to prevent undue friction.

column12: Improvements in Piston and like Packing.
column13: 11,480. Allen, R. May 16. Pistons; Piston packing.-The joints of packing- rings are covered by choke-pieces b having circular or other stems b<2> which pass transversely through recesses in the rings and have oblique end faces, or are bored obliquely, to be acted on by oblique springs c, which cause the choke-pieces to follow the expanding movement of the rings. The packing-rings may be expanded by oblique springs. In the form shown in Figs. 3 and 4<a>, the oblique springs c are lodged in recesses in a ring g between the packing-rings a, a<1> and act on the choke-pieces b through studs d, and the joint-covering parts b<1> have curved bearings in the end plates h of the piston, which are secured against a collar i<1> on the rod i and the ring g by bolts j. The choke-pieces are formed with parts b<3> passing through the packing-rings and flush therewith to retain the choke-pieces when the parts b<1> pass into the ends of a cylinder with greater bore at the ends. Fig. 3 shows a vulcanite packing-ring having a metal bearing a<2> for the studs d of the expanding-springs. In the trunk piston shown in Fig. 11, the springs c are lodged in sockets m let into the piston, and the joint-covering parts b<1> have flat bearings in a ring k, which is prevented from rotating by studs when the end ring of the piston is screwed on. In a modification, Fig. 9<a>, the springs are lodged in recesses in an obliquely-arranged ring l. In a modification applied to a piston for terminalexhaust engines, which comprises two parts having a stepped annular joint with lead-wire packing between them, the springs are lodged in recesses in the choke-pieces.

column12: Whippella "water saver-warmer"
Improvements in Pistons and Piston Valves.
column13: 28,808. Allen, R. Dec. 13. Piston valves.-A piston valve is formed with separable ends clamping between them a cylindrical body portion and one or more collars on the rod. The piston shown consists of end plates c, c<1> clamping a collar g on the piston rod and spaced apart by a hollow body a. The parts are braced together by bolts d. The thrust may be taken by sleeves h, by shoulders on the bolts d, by spacing struts or by a spacing ring formed with projections bearing on the plates c, c<1>. The plate c is held in position during examination of the piston by a stud k. The piston rings may bear directly on the plates c, c<1> or on cast iron rings housed in recesses in the rings c, c<1>. In a modification, the piston has a long body a, and the rod f is formed with two collars g separated by a neck. The hearing-surfaces on the plates for the body n and the collars g may be in the same plane in order to facilitate machining. The body a may be formed to overlap the plates c in order to separate the packing-rings as much as possible.

column12: Perfectionnements aux pistons, pistons-valves et organes analogues
Improvements in Pistons and Piston Packing.
column13: 28,719. Allen. R. Dec. 29. Pistons.-Relates to piston packing consisting of segmental rings expanded by wedges pressed forwards by springs or fluid pressure as shown in Fig. 9, and consists in forming the wedges with wearing-surfaces of soft metal. The wedge shown in plan and sectional elevation in Fig. 2 has a body a of soft metal, to which a hard metal wedge c is secured between the forks b by a rivet e or otherwise. A nose d of soft metal is brazed or otherwise secured in a dovetail groove in the wedge c. In the modified wedge shown in Fig. 4, the wedge part c is formed in one with the body a, and a nose d of soft metal is carried by a cap f of steel or other hard metal. The nose d may be held between two plates secured to the wedge part c, or the nose may be formed in one with the part e, the sides of which are protected by steel plates let into recesses. Fig. 6 shows a wedge of bard metal, the upper part of which is covered by a soft-metal cap g secured in position by ribs hand by pins and, when the cap is of soft brass or copper, by brazing. The upper part of the hardmetal wedge may be conical, the under part of the cap being conical also. The ends of the segments i, Fig. 9, are protected by steel plates j.

column12: Improvements in Gun Mountings for Aeroplanes.
column13: 124,872. Allen, R. March 28, 1918. Mountings for use on aircraft; recoil apparatus. -Relates to mountings applicable to the top planes of aeroplanes and comprising. as shown in Fig. 5, a forwardly-extending girder c and a downwardly-curved quadrant e having a slideblock d, carrying the gun, mounted thereon, the slide-block being under the influence of springs which exert an upward and forward pull and serve as shock-absorbers. According to the invention, the shock-absorber comprises one or more india-rubber springs. In the construction shown in Fig. 1, a rubber spring a is attached at the rear end to the block d sliding on the quadrant e, and at the front to the girder c. The point of attachment at the front can be altered to adjust the tension of the spring. The spring passes over a pulley g carried at the rear end of the girder. In a modification, Fig. 5, two springs, one at each side of the girder, are provided.

column12: Improvements in Shrapnel Shells.
column13: 127,906. Allen, R. July 31, 1915. Projectiles. - Consists ir casting bullets for shrapne shells integral with thin webs or disks. The webbed layers of bullets a, which are preferably of cast iron, may bE in close contact, as shown ir Fig. 1, or may be spaced apart by iron rings. Highexplosive or smoke-producing material may fill the spaces between the bullets. In shells in which there is a tubular bolt or tensile mem. ber, the shrapnel filling may be placed both inside and out. side the tube, perforated spac. ing-rings being provided in the tube. Specification 9302/15 is referred to.

column12: Improvements in the Manufacture of Obturator or Packing Rings for Pistons.
column13: 100,907. Allen, R. April 7, 1916. Rings.-Packing-rings of the Ramsbottom type, or of the type used in the Gnome engine, are simultaneously pressed to shape and peened by means of a hammer or press. The packing-ring c<1> is placed in a die a, and is acted on by a hammer ring d, which may be formed, as shown, with teeth acting as hammer faces. The hammer ring is split or is formed in sections, and is expanded by the descent of the tup e, to which it may be connected by means of studs f. The axis of the tup is preferably eccentric to the die, in order that the packing-ring may be more highly compressed at the part remote :'rom the split. A guiding-projection on the tup may enter the central hole in the plate b which is employed to lift the ring out of the die.

column12: Piston
Improvements in Lewis Automatic Machine Guns.
column13: 129,093. Allen, R. June 29, 1919. Machine guns.-Consists in replacing the ordinary mainspring of a Lewis gun by elongated tension springs of india-rubber or metal attached at the front to a fixed part of the gun and at the rear to the reciprocating breech mechanism. Preferably, there are two springs, one on each side of the gun. In the construction shown in Figs. 1 and 2, there are two india-rubber springs b secured at the rear to a reciprocating cross-bar p, and at the front secured by wires k on tensioning- reels j. The reels are provided with a turning- head g and with a ratchet-wheel h engaged by a pawl i. In a modification, Fig. 7, the tensioning- reels can be rotated from the breech-end of the gun by means of a wire r wound on a wheel t, formed on or fixed to the same spindle as the reels, and also on a winding-reel f, which is provided with a ratchet-wheel and a turning-head. Methods of detachably connecting the springs to the breech mechanism are shown in Figs. 14 and 16. In the construction shown in Fig. 14, the rear fitting u of the spring is flanged and is secured by being pressed into a spring clip v connected to the breech mechanism. In the modification shown in Fig. 16, a coupling-cable w is employed, having ball-and-socket connexions with the clip v and with the end of the spring. The india-rubber springs are preferably composed of strarids of rubber increasing in thickness from the two ends to the centre, covered with cotton, asbestos, or wire. A rubber spring may be enclosed in a closely coiled helical spring b<1>, Fig. 17.

column12: Perfectionnements à la fabrication des segments de pistons
WORD REGISTER FOR TYPEWRITERS
Improvements in Pistons or Piston Valves.
column13: 26,668. Allen, R. Nov. 16. [Cognate Applications, 8535/11 and 11,790/11.] Piston packing. - Undue expansion of segmental piston packing by the working fluid is prevented either by friction between the packing and the side of its groove, or by excluding working fluid from the back of the packing. Packing - rings may be pressed axially and radially by inclined springs, and grit may be collected by grooved rings. In the arrangements shown in Figs. 1 and 2, segments a are pressed outwards by wedges b acted on by helical springs c. The grooves d are wider than the packing-rings, which are pressed against one side of a groove by the fluid pressure and by springs g. The wearing-surfaces of the rings are reduced, either by being cut away, as shown, or by means of grooves. The springs g may be replaced by projections on the segments, which hold the rings away from one side of a groove. This arrangement may be modified by arranging the springs g to press the packing-rings against the high-pressure side of a groove, thus excluding pressure fluid from the back of the packing. In a modified arrangement, grooves are dispensed with, the packing-rings being arranged at the sides of a carrier, and guided by studs passing through slots in the packing-rings. In the arrangement shown in Figs. 7 and 8, the packing-rings are arranged between non- expanding rings m and a carrier. The carrier is formed in halves secured together, and having either overlapping ends or butt ends and coverplates e<7> secured by pegs e<5>, which may be withdrawn by means of studs inserted through holes r<1>. Where necessary, the rings m are also formed in halves secured together. The wedges b are expanded by leaf springs c<1> formed with heads c<2> dovetailed into the wedges. Fig. 10 shows a ring m in two parts, which are prevented from expanding and rotating by pegs m<2>, and are acted on by leaf springs n. Fig. 22 shows the segments a and the wedges pressed both radially and axially by inclined springs g<3>. Some of the cups h slide in grooves h<1> to prevent rotation. The piston of an internal-combustion engine is provided with one or more grooved rings t, Fig. 26. Grit collecting in the grooves passes through holes t<3> to the backs of the rings. The rings may be in parts secured to the piston by studs t<4>. Provisional Specification 8535/11 describes also a method of causing slow rotation of packing-rings by arranging the grooves containing the rings at an angle to the axis of the piston.

column12: Piston or piston valve
Improvements in or relating to the Grates or Fuel Supports of Road or Railway Locomotive Engines.
column13: 12,576. Allen, R. Sept. 1. Grates; ash-pans.-In a road or railway locomotive of the kind in which the grate and ash-pan are combined in one unit adapted to be raised and lowered for cleaning and inspection purposes, hooks are provided on opposite sides of the ash-pan, by which it is suspended by chains attached to winding-gear. In the Figure, the combined ash. pan and grate is shown in its raised and lowered positions. The grate c is supported on a frame d secured to the ash-pan a by bars d<1>. The ash-pan is provided with a flange e adapted to bear against the fire-box. Suspending-chains h attached to hooks f on the ash-pan unite in a single chain h<1>, which passes over a chain-wheel k and is attached to a weight l at its free end. A bar i passes through the hooks f and engages with lugs attached to the fire-box, thus serving to secure the ash-pan and grate in position. The bar i may be dispensed with and replaced by studs attached to the fire-box and engaging with the flange e of the ash-pan.

column12: Improvements in Pistons.
column13: 27,659. Allen, R. May 5. Pistons.-To take up the wear of the piston of a horizontal cylinder, an adjustable centring-ring, separate from the packing, is mounted on the piston. The ring a is housed between a junk ring and a flange on the piston, and is formed with a number of in. clined surfaces p, with which wedges o, o<1> are adapted to engage. These wedges are moved either by right and left band screwthreads on crosspins, or by screwing the hollow bolts q<3> into one of each pair of the wedges, the bolts q<2> passing through the hollow bolts and screwing into the other wedges ; the two bolts are connected together by a pin r so as to move simultaneously. A pin p<2> prevents rotation of the centring-ring. When the piston is formed without a junk ring, the centring- ring is in two parts bolted together by plates a<1>. The wedges are situated at the bottom of the piston, but the ring is provided with inclined surfaces around its circumferences to permit displace. ment for taking up the wear on the ring. In place of the wedges, thin plates inserted between the ring and piston body may be used to adjust the ring. Ordinary picking-rings are used in addition to the centring-ring.

column12: Gun-mounting for use on aircraft
CONTROL VALVE
Adjustable alarm device for sliding doors and windows
column13: An adjustable alarm device for windows and doors is installed between the door or window frame and the door or window sash. The longitudinal axis of the alarm device is preferably horizontal. When engaged, movement of the door or window in an open direction will activate the alarm. The body of the alarm device is elongate, tubular and telescoping. The body comprises an outer tube that receives an inner tube. The body of the alarm device may be locked in an extended position by way of a cam mounted on the inner tube and positioned within the body so that when the inner and outer tubes of the body are twisted about their longitudinal axis, the cam body will engage the inner surface of the outer tube in a releasable frictional locking engagement. The alarm device is coupled to one end of the inner tube.

column12: PISTON

Improvements in Pistons.
column13: 178. Allen, R. Jan. 3. Pistons, balancing laterally and reducing and equalizing wear of.-In a piston which is provided with an adjustable centring-ring b<1> for taking up wear, wedging-means for centring are applied at or near the centre of the piston head. The means may comprise a screw plug j having a conical surface, adapted to force outwards radial rods l taking against an inner ring rigidly connected to the centring- ring b<1> which works between the end plates a, a<1> of the piston held in position by screw studs m and screws c. In modifications, the end plates may screw on the pistonrod or may be secured in position by a screw cap which also encloses the plug j and its lock-ring j<1>.

column12: Twisted pair cable having improved crosstalk isolation
column13: A cable that provides reduced alien crosstalk between similar twisted pairs in cables that are in close proximity to one another and/or crosstalk between twisted pairs of the cable. In one example, a cable includes a first twisted pair of insulated conductors, a second twisted pair of insulated conductors, a shaped separator positioned so as to separate the first twisted pair from the second twisted pair, and a jacket disposed about the first and second twisted pairs and the separator, wherein the shaped separator comprises a central arm and at least one enlarged portion disposed at a first end of the central arm.

column13: An adjustable alarm device for windows and doors is installed between the door or window frame and the door or window sash. The longitudinal axis of the alarm device is preferably horizontal. When engaged, movement of the door or window in an open direction will activate the alarm. The body of the alarm device is elongate, tubular and telescoping. The body comprises an outer tube that receives an inner tube. column12: Improvements in Street or Road Cleaning Machines.
column13: 3564. Allen, R. Feb. 14. Sweeping-machines; scraping- machines.-A m a c h i n e for sweeping or scraping roads and at the same time elevating the sweepings or scrapings into a cart is constructed with an endless chain of brushes or scrapers d working in an inclined trough a, which is arranged to discharge the sweepings into a cart to which the machine is coupled. The trough is mounted on a pair of wheels b<1>, the axle of which is also connected by a frame e to a single rear steering-wheel b<2> controlled by a hand - wheel h. The brushes pass over rollers k, k<1>, k<2> mounted in a frame l, and the roller k is driven by chains t, spur gearing s, s', and ratchets from the wheels b<1>. The upper end of the frame l is adjusted in relation to the trough by racks n and pinions p. Springs m, provided with adjusting-screws, and carried by brackets a<3> on the trough, press the brushes on to the road. The bearings of the rollers k<1>, k<2> may be adjusted by racks or screws. The brushes can be raised off the road by a lever u. The sides of the trough are inclined outwards at the lower end, and are fitted with adjustable extensions v<1>. The bottom of the trough is fitted with an adjustable trailing apron a' made of a number of hinged pieces. The part in contact with the road may be of rubber. A spiked roller w removes the dirt from the brushes. The chains may be fitted with brushes and scrapers combined, or with squeegees combined with either. The brushing-apparatus may be inclined to one side so as to sweep out gutters. In a hand machine, a box or bag receptacle is supported on brackets on the trough or brush frame or is suspended directly therefrom.

column12: Water-Blocked Cable
column13: A water-blocked cable comprised of a first and second line of defense against water invasion wherein said cable is comprised of materials that can meet both indoor and outdoor use requirements.

column12: PISTON RING
Zoom zoom
column13: A vehicle capable of turning 360° includes a steering apparatus to steer the vehicle, and a wheel to turn the vehicle and to be responsive to the steering apparatus. The wheel turns the vehicle 360° without reversing.

column12: PISTON ROD PACKING
Improvements in Pistons.
column13: 29,128. Allen, R. Dec. 27. [Addition to 27,659/08.] Pistons, balancing laterally and reducing and equalizing wear of.-Relates to the cen tring-rings described in the parent Specification for supporting horizontal pistons and equalizing their wear, and consists in replacing the double wedges by single wedges, and in an improved segmental centring - ring. The ring a is adjusted by set-screws g<1>, which may screw into the centring-ring as shown, or into the junk ring c'. In the case of a ring with no removable junk ring, the centring-ring may be built up as shown of two segmental rings with engaging ribs a' and grooves a<2>. The rings are held in their relative positions by a pin j.

column12: An Improved Apparatus for Surface Heating and Cooling applicable as a Condenser and Feed Water or Air Heater.
column13: 21,701. Allen, R. Oct. 6. Feedwater, heating.-An apparatus for heating and cooling liquids and gases generally, and applicable also as a condenser and feedwater or air heater for a steam engine, is composed of a number of thin flat or corrugated plates b, Fig. 2 disposed one above the other and separated by frames a, which form distance-pieces. Suitable packing is placed between the edges of the plates and the frames, and the whole is closed by end covers d and secured together by means of bolts e. The spaces between the plates are connected together alternately, to form two distinct continuous passages through the apparatus, by means of ports g in the frames a. Preferably, these ports are arranged so that the liquids or gases can pass through the adjacent passages in a direction at right-angles to each other. Inlet and outlet connections to the separate passages are shown at h, i, j, k and filling-plates l, with bevelled ends, are placed between the plates to divide the currents passing through the spaces and force them into contact with the heating or cooling surfaces. In one modification, Fig. 4, the plates a are separated by solid bars or distance-pieces n and by perforated supports o which also serve to prevent distortion of the plates. The plates are enclosed in a castiron casing p, and the whole is secured together by bolts q. Webs are provided on the inside of the end covers of the casing to make the liquids or gases pass in a sinuous course. In a second modification, the tiers of plates and distance-pieces are cast in one piece and enclosed in a casing as before. When employed as a condenser and feedwater or air heater for a steam engine, the exhaust steam is passed through one set of alternate spaces, and the air or water, or both, circulated at right-angles to it through the other spaces. The invention is also applicable for warming buildings by passing steam and air through the two sets of spaces.

column12: AN ADJUSTABLE ALARM DEVICE FOR SLIDING DOORS AND WINDOWS
column13: An adjustable alarm device for windows and doors is installed between the do or or window frame and the door or window sash. The longitudinal axis of the alarm device is preferably horizontal. When engaged, movement of the door or window in an open directio n will activate the alarm. The body of the alarm device is elongate, tubular and telescoping. Th e body comprises an outer tube that receives an inner tube. The body of the alarm device may be locked in an extended position by way of a cam mounted on the inner tube and positioned within the body so that when the inner and outer tubes of the body are twisted about their longitudinal axis, the cam body will engage the inner surface of the outer tube in a releasable frictional lockin g engagement. The alarm device is coupled to one end of the inner tube.

column12: Garniture perfectionnée pour tiges de pistons
CONTAINER WITH INDICATING CLOSURE
column13: A container for pharmaceuticals and the like has a cap-like closure incorporating an indicator disk which is automatically indexed into successive indicating positions each time the container is used by removal and replacement of the closure. The container also has a manually operable rotary reminder wheel on its base. The disk may be used to indicate days of the week and the wheel to indicate hours of the day.

column12: Foam soap dispensing apparatus
column13: A foam soap dispensing apparatus 100 comprising a connection point 121 for a first reservoir 110, a pipe 120 connected to the connection point, a second reservoir (140, fig 4) connected to the other end of the pipe arranged vertically lower than the connection point and an outlet (143, fig 5) from the second reservoir for dispensing soap. The first reservoir comprises a removable cartridge and the path of the pipe descends vertically between the connection point and the second reservoir. The removable cartridge may form the first reservoir, and preferably the second reservoir is collapsible to provide an air-tight apparatus to isolate airborne contaminants. The path of the pipe may be a coil or spiral, connecting to the underside of the upper reservoir and to the top of the lower reservoir. To the apparatus can be refilled before empty by replacing the cartridge of the first reservoir. The apparatus may be a multi-feed dispensing apparatus (10, fig 1).

column12: PISTON, PISTON VALVE, ETC.
Improvements in Projectiles for Ordnance.
column13: 9302. Allen, R. July 31. Projectiles.-Consists in forming the head, body, and base of a shell separately, and securing them together with shock-absorbing joints between them, by means of one or more tensile members connected to the head and base. In the shell shown in Fig. 1, the body consists of a plain cylindrical forging or casting a recessed at each end to receive the head h and base b respectively, the joints being secured by radial pins i, b<1>. A central tube k is screwed at one end to a flanged steel nut f in the base, and at the other end to a nose j. The tube k, which is perforated, may form a priming tube, or in large shells may contain part of the explosive charge and have a priming tube within it. Instead of a single tubular bolt k, several concentric bolts may in some cases be provided. A shrapnel shell is described in which the central tube screws directly into the head and base, separate nuts being dispensed with. An armour-piercing shell is shown in Fig. 4, comprising a steel nose m integral with a bolt k which is screwed into a nut f in the base. The head h may be centred on the upper end of the body a by a ring o having an annular rib fitting an internal groove in the joint. Dowel pins n are inserted in the joints between the body and the head and base respectively. In another construction, a V-groove is provided in the base for receiving the tapered end of the body portion. In all cases, malleable metal collars or washers are provided in the joints to render them gas-tight and absorb shock. An outer winding of high-tensile steel wire q or the like may be provided on the shell body, Fig. 6. The wire is preferably wound on when red hot, and the ends may be welded. Several methods of securing the copper driving-band c are described, two of which are shown in Figs. 1 and 4, where copper or other fixing-pins are shown. The groove for the band may be serrated at the sides, or the bottom of the groove may be ribbed. The band is preferably shrunk on. Cast iron, steel, or semi-steel, malleable cast iron, or solid-drawn steel tubing may be used in manufacturing the parts of the shells.

column12: Improvements in Pistons.
column13: 30,078. Allen, R. Dec. 23. [Cognate Application, 30,079/09.] Piston packing; piston - packing substitutes; pistons. - Relates to packing for pistons and piston - valves which is kept against the sides of the grooves containing it by wedging-means In the form shown in Fig. 2, the packing b, consisting of divided rings expanded by spring wedges b<3> and separated by solid rings g, is adjusted axially by an expanding wedge-ring h; and one or more perforated floating rings d with spaces f behind them are provided between the packing and the working end of the piston to allow the motive fluid to expand and to arrest solid matter In the form shown in Fig. 3, two solid rings g, forced apart by a wedge-ring h expanded by spring wedges h<2>, are placed between the packing-rings b, the wedges b<3> of which are forced outwards by axial spring wedges b<4>. In a modification of this form, the wedge-ring h is also expanded by axial wedges. In another modification, the solid rings g are forced apart by springs, and the wedges b<3> are forced outwards by springs bearing on floating rings. In the form shown in Fig. 11, the wedges b<3> of the packing - rings have pivoted shanks m<3> passing through holes in floating rings m and are forced outwards by leaf-springs m<1>. Another form of wedge for expanding the packing-rings b or the wedge-rings h, Fig. 17, comprises a part h<2> bearing against the packing- ring or wedge-ring and a part o bearing on the piston or on a floating ring, the two parts being correspondingly bevelled and drawn together by a spring. The packing and the solid rings g may be contained between end rings, so that the whole may be removed together from the piston.

column13: 4135. Allen, R. Feb. 19. [Addition to 17,437/07.] Packing, metallic; packing, removable casings, containers, or carriers for.-Relates to the packing described in the parent Specification, in which segmental packing-rings are formed with wedge ends acted on by radial wedge blocks. In the form shown in Figs. 5 and 6, segmental or split rings a, a<1> are contracted by wedges c, in which the head c is formed separate from the shank b and is secured to it by a nut c<2>. The shank is formed with an extension for covering the joint. Where two or three rings are arranged in the same joint, they are formed with bevelled surfaces, and one ring acting as the wedging-ring may alone be acted on by contracting wedges, the other rings having wedges of the form shown at c<3> for covering the joints and preventing rotation. The packing-rings are arranged in grooves in rings d secured in an outer casing e by a screw ring f. The joint between the casing and the stuffing-box is made by a cup-leather or other packing h. In a box for a rotary shaft, rotation is prevented by a key between the rings d and the casing e and projections k on the casing entering recesses in the box. In the form shown in Fig. 7, the wedges are acted on by axial spring plungers n. The packing has spherical end joints d, d<1>. In a modified form of joint, the covering-flange of the wedge is formed in the middle, and enters slots in the packing-rings.

column12: Improvements in Pistons.
column13: 24,509. Allen, R. Nov. 5. Pistons.-Pistons are formed with a recess on each face to receive plates a arranged to be simultaneously adjusted, to take up the wear on the lower side of the piston, by means of cams h on bolts i, each of these having a square hole j to receive a spanner. The plates are fixed in position by bolts g with closing-washers g<1>. Packing-rings f of any type are used in the piston. Alternatively the plates are pressed down by springs l, in which case the bolts g hold the plates either loosely or fixed.

column12: Metallic packing for pistons
Improvements in Explosive Shells.
column13: 127,908. Allen, R. July 31, 1915. Tinning, galvanizing, and coating by dipping.- Consists in subjecting the body of an explosive shell, or parts thereof, to a galvanizing or tinning process, so that a metallic lining or coating is applied and fills in the pores or interstices in the metal. The unfilled shells are first supported in a sealed acid bath, and considerable pressure is exerted on the liquid. Preferably the shells are warmed before or during immersion. They are then suspended in a bath of molten solder or tin amalgam under pressure. Electro-deposition may be employed in addition. After removal from the tinning bath, the superfluous metal is allowed to drain off, or is driven out by an air blast.

column12: Medical benefits payment system
column13: A method of facilitating payment of health care benefits to on behalf of a payer comprising the step of electronically transmitting a stored-value card account payment of the authorized benefit amount concurrently with an explanation of benefits.

column12: PLATFORM FOR THE PURCHASE AND SALE OF DIGITAL CURRENCY
column13: A platform for buyers and sellers of digital currency is disclosed. The platform comprises different modules which can be used alone or in combination. When used together, they provide for a fully automated experience for a user, from account sign-up through to funds settlement. Using the platform, a buyer or seller can participate in virtually instantaneous transactions of digital currency. The platform can be expanded to buy and sell other commodities in addition to digital currency. The platform can permit users to fund or settle accounts using commodities such as gold rather than a globally traded currency.

Stopfbüchsenpackung mit mehrteiligen Dichtungsringen.
Improvements in and relating to Furnace Grates.
column13: 15,894. Allen, R. July 10. Fire bars and grafes.-In a furnace grate in which sets of alternate fire - bars are raised and lowered at opposite ends, toothed or serrated lifting-bars, operated by rack and pinion and bevel gearing, are employed. The fire-bars c are supported on fixed bearers b, and are operated by notched lifting-bars a having projections a<2> engaging notches c' in the webs c' by which the bars are positively returned to position. The fire-bars have half bearings c<9> at one end, and are flat at the opposite or lifting end. The lifting-bars a are actuated by a mechanically or manually operated shaft h having pinions g engaging depending racks f, Fig. 8. In the arrangement shown, the shaft is operated by bevel-gearing o, a quadrant m, and rack l connected to the piston of a steam-cylinder k. Each rack and pinion f, g is housed in a casing i to prevent the clogging of the gearing by ashes. Large grates are divided into two or more sections, the bars of which are operated either independently or together, and two racks actuated by geared pinions may be provided on each lifting-bar. The firebars c are formed with a groove c' in the upper surface and side notches c<5>. The contact surfaces c<7> of the fire-bars and the contact surfaces of the lifting and bearer bars are provided with notches or grooves to prevent the adherence of clinker &c.

column13: A Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) sensory symptoms monitoring device for recording and analyzing, with the use of a personal computer, the RLS sensory symptoms of one wearing the device during a specified test period in which the wearer complies with a given test protocol includes: (a) a switch for the wearer to input, at prescribed time intervals during the test period, the wearer's RLS sensory symptoms assessment, (b) an alarm for indicating to the wearer the instances of the prescribed times during the period when the assessments are to be made and inputted into the device, (c) a sensor that measures the compliance of the wearer with the test protocol, (d) a microprocessor having embedded programmable memory, (e) a storage element for the inputted assessments and data, and (f) firmware for controlling the microprocessor's operation.

column12: PACKING FOR RODS AND THE LIKE.
An Improved Packing for Piston Rods and the like.
column13: 8470. Allen, R. April 10. [Addition to 26,674/10.] Packing, metallic; packing, non-metallic; followers, bushes, and the like; packing, inserting and extracting; packing, adjusting; stuffing - boxes, substitutes for.-Improvements in packing of the type described in the parent Specification consist in arranging the inexpansible rings c which form the abutments for the oblique springs to fit the rod instead of fitting the stuffing-box, in forming the abutment rings, followers, and bushes in halves, and in facing the packing-rings with vulcanite. As shown in Fig. 3, one or more segmental rings d are employed, acted upon by oblique springs j. The rings are of the type in which the wearing-surface is small in comparison with the lateral surface in order to prevent undue expansion by leakage fluid. The rings c forming abutments for the springs j fit the rod instead of the stuffing-box. In order to facilitate insertion of the abutment rings c, and the follower rings and bushes e<1>, h, h<1>, &c., these rings may be made in halves secured together by solid rings e<2> received in recesses in the rings. A set-screw m serves to secure the separating- ring l during renewal of the soft self-lubricating packing f. This packing is compressed by a follower h acted on by springs i. The bushes, followers, abutment rings, &c. are formed with grooves which act as additional packing.

column12: Improvements in Lewis Automatic Machine Guns.
column13: 135,930. Allen, R. Dec. 3, 1918. Machine guns. -Relates to Lewis guns fitted with rubber or metal elongated tension springs a of the kind described in Specification 129,093, and consists in providing (1) a passage h<1>, preferably a tubular bolt, in the mounting yoke h for the spring or its coupling-rod b, (2) a notch on the cocking-handle c for the engagement of a slotted enlargement c on the coupling-rod, and (3) a metal strip i attachable in various positions in the muzzle end of the gun by a screw-pin j so as to alter the initial tension of the spring as desired. Where two springs are provided, similar guides and attachments are provided on both sides of the gun.

column12: System and method for treating articles with fluids
column13: The present invention provides a method for efficiently and uniformly treating articles with two or more fluids without transferring the articles from one container to another container. The method comprises: providing the fluids, one at a time, to treat the articles in a treatment system, wherein the treatment system comprises one or more trays each of which has one or more baskets, each basket capable of holding one article, and wherein said trays are stacked to form a vessel or are stacked and placed within a preformed vessel, said vessel or preformed vessel comprising a first entrance/exit and a second entrance/exit for the fluids; and each time one of the fluids is provided to treat the articles, (a) flushing continuously the articles with the fluid in a first flow direction from the first entrance/exit to the second entrance/exit, (b) reversing the flow direction of the fluid, (c) flushing continuously the articles with the fluid in a second direction from the second entrance/exit to the first entrance/exit for a second period of time, and (d) if necessary, repeating steps (a) to (c) for a desired number of times.

column12: SYSTEM AND METHOD FOR PROCESSING OBJECT WITH LIQUID
column13: PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide a method for effectively, economically and equally processing an object with one or more types of liquid and particularly, a method capable of performing a plurality of wet processes without moving the object. SOLUTION: This method for processing an object with liquid includes a process in which trays are accumulated to form a container or arranged in a preformed container and the container or the preformed container inputs an object in a processing system including first and second outlets/inlets for liquid while the method has one or more trays, each of the trays has one or more baskets, and each basket can hold one object (1), a process in which the fluid is caused to continuously flow to the object in a first flowing direction from the first outlet/inlet to the second outlet/inlet for a first period (2), a process for reversing the flowing direction of the liquid (3) and a process in which the liquid is caused to continuously flow to the object in a second flowing direction from the second outlet/inlet to the first outlet/inlet for a second period (4).

column12: Cable assembly, terminal assembly, and flowmeter
column13: The utility model relates to a cable assembly, a terminal assembly, and a flowmeter. The cable assembly for being connected with a transducer comprises a plug body, a cable restriction device, and a cable, wherein the plug body comprises a front end portion segment with a front end portion and a tail end portion segment with a tail end portion opposite to the front end portion, the cable restriction device is arranged near the tail end portion, and the cable includes a first end portion, a second end portion, a signal conductor, and a flexible fixing member. A part of the flexible fixing member is arranged in the cable restriction device and at least partially extended by surrounding the plug body in order to the restrict movement of the first end portion of the cable with respect to the plug body.

column12: Fungicidal methods and compositions for killing yeast and sporular microorganisms
column13: Methods and compositions are provided for killing or inhibiting the growth of yeast or sporular microorganisms by contacting the microorganisms, in the presence of a peroxide and chloride or bromide, with a haloperoxidase and at least one antimicrobial activity enhancing agent. Suitable antimicrobial activity enhancing agents include certain alpha -amino acids, and are preferably compounds of the formula: <IMAGE> wherein R1 is hydrogen, an unsubstituted, or hydroxy or amino substituted, straight or branched chain alkyl group having from 1 to 6 carbon atoms, or an unsubstituted, or hydroxy or amino substituted arylalky group having from 7 to 12 carbon atoms, and R2 is hydrogen or a straight or branched chain alkyl group having from 1 to 6 carbon atoms. The significantly enhanced haloperoxidase antiyeast and antispore activities make the methods and compositions of the invention highly useful in the therapeutic or prophylactic antiseptic treatment of human or animal subjects and in in vitro applications for disinfection or sterilization of vegetative microbes, yeasts, and bacterial and fungal spores. Suitable haloperoxidases for use in the methods and compositions of the invention include eosinophil peroxidase (EPO) and myeloperoxidase (MPO). Representative antimicrobial activity enhancing agents of the invention include alpha -amino acids selected from the group consisting of glycine and the l- or d-enantiomers of alanine, valine, leucine, isoleucine, serine, threonine, lysine, phenylalanine, tyrosine, and the alkyl esters thereof.

column12: AMINO AND FLUORO GROUP CONTAINING SILOXANES, EMULSIONS AND SURFACE COATINGS THEREOF
column13: Novel polymeric fluorocarbon siloxane represented by the formula: R1-[- OSi(Ra)(OR1)]x-[-OSi(Rb)(OR1)]y-[-OSi(Rc)(OR1)]z-OR1, and corresponding polymeric branched structures wherein Ra is a perfluoroalkyl radical, Rb is an aminoalkyl or substituted aminoalkyl radical and Rc hydrocarbyl, substituted hydrocarbyl phenyl, substituted phenyl or cyanoalkyl radical are shown to fo rm stable aqueous emulsions without the use of volatile organic solvents and by a low energy processing. These emulsions are found to be highly hydrolyzed in solution without leading to precipitation via intermolecular condensation. T he emulsions when applied to substrates impart both oil and water repellent properties as well as improved lubricity.

column12: Stacked Catheter Tray, System, and Associated Methods
column13: A tray stack ( 100 ) for accommodating a catheter assembly ( 1400 ) and medical devices ( 1401,1402,1403,1404,1409,1410, 1411,1412,1413 ) corresponding to catheter use includes a first tray ( 101 ) and second tray ( 102 ). Each tray ( 101,102 ) includes a tray opening, a base member ( 205,206 ), and sidewalls ( 203,204 ). When placed atop each other, they first tray ( 101 ) and second tray ( 102 ) form a tray stack ( 100 ). When unstacked and placed in a side-by-side, single layer catheter tray assembly ( 200 ), implements disposed therein can be arranged in a predetermined sequence corresponding to an order of use during a catheterization procedure. Mechanical couplings ( 300 ) can be included to permit the trays to translate with respect to each other. Retention mechanisms ( 710 - 713 ) can be included to hold the trays together.

column12: Turbine-blade lashing
ASYNCHRONOUS JITTER REDUCTION TECHNIQUE
column13: The amount of jitter incurred when reading data written into a FIFO (12) can be reduced by clocking the FIFO with Read Clock pulses at a frequency x fn where x is a whole integer and fn is the frequency at which the memory is clocked to write data. Read Addresses are applied to the FIFO at a frequency on the order of fn to identify successive locations in the memory for reading when the memory is clocked with read clocked pulses to enable reading of samples stored at such successive locations. column12: Utilizing Ray Tracing for Enhanced Artificial Intelligence Path-Finding
column13: Embodiments of the invention provide methods and apparatus to use ray-tracing to perform artificial intelligence path-finding. Embodiments of the invention may cast a ray into a three-dimensional scene to determine a path from a starting point to an ending point. The ray may have a trajectory which originates at the starting point and proceeds towards the ending point. The artificial intelligence system may perform ray-tracing using a spatial index to determine if the ray intersects any objects within the three-dimensional scene. If the ray reaches the ending point without intersecting any objects, the path of the ray from the starting point to the ending point is the determined path. However, if the ray intersects an object, the artificial intelligence system may cast additional rays into the three-dimensional scene and perform ray tracing with the additional rays to determine a path from the start point to the end point.

column13: 10,111. Gillespie, R. A. May 4. Clip and sleeve joints; cotcplings, attaching pipes to.-Relates to couplings for uniting pipes with plain ends in gas, water, or other mains. The sleeve 3 is fitted over the pipe ends, and is provided with stuffing-boxes at each end in which the rubber packing-rings 5 are compressed by the glands 4. The bottom of the stuffing-boxes . is formed with a double bevel 6, 7, the packing-ring being formed similarly, so that the ridge 8 is formed for holding the packing-ring. The gland 4 is provided with recesses into which the dogs 17 are fitted, and projections on the dogs are forced into the pipes by means of the transverse wedges 20 ; longitudinal stresses on the coupling force the dogs further into the pipe. The glands are first brought into position by temporary bolts 22 and the wedges are then inserted. A modification is described in which the dogs are dispensed with and the gland is serrated for engaging the wedges, and in another modification, the sleeve is not provided with a stuffing-box, but the packing-rings are forced against the ends of the sleeve by means of rings at each end connected together by bolts.

column12: Stripe on strip plating method
column13: An apparatus is described for selectively depositing a continuous stripe of one type of material on a strip of another type of material as the strip is transported through the apparatus on a path of spaced rails. The rails are provided for supporting the strip along its lateral edges. A weight or pressure in the form of a movable member is carried on the strip between tape-guiding means for forming a fluid-tight seal between the lateral edges of the strip and the rails. A plurality of fluid jets are provided in a line between the rails for jetting fluid against the strip. At opposite ends of the line of jets there is provided at least one fluid jet for jetting fluid inwardly against the back-spray of fluid from the strip for preventing the escape of spent fluid from between the rails and preventing plating in unwanted areas. Means are also provided for changing the width and position of the stripe on the strip by changing the relative position of the rails and strip-guiding means. For the electrodeposition of metal stripes, an electrode in the form of a wire mesh screen is employed between the jets and strip with means provided for providing an electrical potential between the screen and the strip.

OXYGEN ACTIVATABLE FORMULATIONS FOR DISINFECTION OR STERILIZATION
column13: Methods and compositions are disclosed for producing air-activated, i.e., oxygen (O2) activated, disinfectant-sterilent solutions. Solutions containing a haloperoxidase (i.e., a halide:hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) oxidoreductase, such as myeloperoxidase, eosinophil peroxidase or lactoperoxidase) plus a halide or combination of halides (i.e., chloride, bromide and/or iodide), an oxidase (i.e., a substrate:O2 oxidoreductase) capable of generating H2O2, and a substrate specific for that oxidase, are separately prepared under aerobic conditions, but all of the component solutions are made anaerobic prior to final combination and mixing. The anaerobic formulations are dispensed into containers capable of maintaining the anaerobic condition (e.g., pressurized canisters). Dispensing the solution at the time of use exposes the formulation to air (i.e., O2) which activates its disinfectant-sterilent properties. O2 is the rate limiting component for oxidase generation of H2O2. Under aerobic conditions the oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of its substrate and the reduction of O2 to generate H2O2. In turn, H2O2 serves as substrate for haloperoxidase which catalyzes the oxidation of halide to hypohalous acid. Hypohalous acid reacts with an additional H2O2 to generate singlet molecular oxygen (1O2). Hypohalous acid (e.g., hypochlorous acid) and especially 1O2 are potent microbicidal agents. Both haloperoxidase generation of hypohalous acid and its reactive consumption to yield 1O2 are dependent on the availability of H2O2. A high rate of H2O2 generation does not result in the accumulation of hypohalous acid, but instead results in a high rate of 1O2 production. The microbicidal capacity and toxicity of 1O2 are limited by the half-life of this metastable electronically excited reactant, and as such, disinfectant-sterilent activity is temporally defined by and confined to the dynamics of oxidant generation. The disinfectant-sterilent activity of formulation requires air exposure and is dependent on the presence of the halide-haloperoxidase combination employed, the activity of the oxidase present, the availability of oxidase-specific substrate and the availability of O2.

Noise estimation for frequency multiplex communications - measures noise power in unoccupied channel wrt power of white noise over same band
column13: The noise estimator, is intended for frequency multiplex multi-channel communications links, and is carried out by measuring the traffic-to-noise ratio. An unoccupied channel in the link is disconnected and its noise power level is measured in a given band with respect to the noise power from white noise in this same band. The white noise spectrum simulates peak traffic conditions. The unoccupied channel may be a pair of channels specially reserved for test purposes. A filter selects the required frequency band and the noise power is measured by a power meter at the filter output.

column12: Haloperoxidase-Säure-Optimum Chemilumineszenztestsystem
column13: A highly sensitive chemiluminescent indicator system is disclosed for determining the presence or amount of an analyte in a liquid sample. The new acid optimum chemiluminescent indicator system comprises haloperoxidase (halide:hydrogen peroxide oxidoreductase), halide, oxidant and chemiluminigenic substrate. The indicator system acts as a synthesizer of highly reactive singlet molecular oxygen (<1>O2), which reacts with the chemiluminigenic substrate to yield an excited state, oxidized reaction product. The excited state reaction product then relaxes to a lower energy (e.g., ground) state with the emission of measurable light in an amount related to the amount of each of the reaction participants present in a reaction solution. Known, non-rate limiting amounts of three of the reaction participants are provided in an assay solution to determine the presence or amount of the fourth participant in a test sample. The fourth participant in the test sample may be the analyte of interest, or may be produced or consumed in the test sample through one or more preliminary reactions involving the ultimate analyte of interest, with the amount of the fourth participant being related to the amount of analyte in the test solution. Accordingly, the indicator system of the invention may be employed for the determination of a wide variety of analytes. The indicator system operates most efficiently over the range from acid to slightly basic pH, e.g., at a pH of about 3 to about 8. Also described is a variety of illustrative assay formats in which the indicator reaction of the invention may be employed, as well as kits for use in carrying out assays utilizing the haloperoxidase/halide/oxidant/substrate indicator system.

column12: MODEL BASED LOAD DEMAND CONTROL.
column13: Embodiments of methods and systems for controlling a load generated by a power generating system may include controlling at least a portion of the system using mode1based control techniques. The model-based control techniques may include a dynamic matrix controller (DMC) that receives a load demand and a process variable as inputs and generates a control signal based on the inputs and a stored model. The model may be configured based on parametric testing, and may be modifiable. Other inputs may also be used to determine the control signal. In an embodiment, a turbine is controlled by a first DMC and a boiler is controlled by a second DMC, and the control signals generated by the first and the second DMCs are used in conjunction to control the generated load. Techniques to move the power generating system from Proportional-Integral-Derivative based control to model-based control are also disclosed.

column12: Methods and Systems for Reducing the Number of Rays Passed Between Processing Elements in a Distributed Ray Tracing System
column13: Embodiments of the invention provide techniques and systems for reducing network traffic in relation to ray-tracing a three dimensional scene. According to one embodiment of the invention, as a ray is traversed through a spatial index, a leaf node may be reached. Subsequent rays that traverse through the spatial index may reach the same leaf node. In contrast to sending information defining a ray issued by the workload manager to a vector throughput engine each time a ray reaches a leaf node, the workload manager may determine if a series of rays reach the same leaf node and send information defining the series of rays to the vector throughput engine. Thus, network traffic may be reduced by sending information which defines a series of rays which are traversed to a common (i.e., the same) leaf node in contrast to sending information each time a ray is traversed to a leaf node.
